title: 5 Quick & Easy Ways to Take a Screenshot with an iPhone

steps.title: Find the image, app or webpage you want to screenshot.
steps.content: Find the image, app or webpage you want to screenshot. When screenshotting, everything on your screen at the time of the screenshot be captured in the image. Use this method if your iPhone does not have a round Home button below the screen.

steps.title: Press the Side button and the Volume Up buttons at the same time.
steps.content: Press the Side button and the Volume Up buttons at the same time. The Volume Up button is on the left side of the phone, and the Side button is on the right side. When you release your fingers from the buttons, the screen will briefly flash white. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the small version of the screenshot to edit it (optional).
steps.content: Tap the small version of the screenshot to edit it (optional). After capturing the screenshot, a small version of it will appear in the bottom-left corner, where it will remain for several seconds. If you tap this preview, it will open for editing in Markup. You can drag the bars on any edge of the image to crop off what you don't need. To draw, tap any of the drawing tools at the bottom, tap the circle to select a color, and then start drawing. Tap Done at the top-left corner when you're finished editing the screenshot.

steps.title: View your screenshot in the Photos app.
steps.content: View your screenshot in the Photos app. To do so, tap the Photos app (the white icon with a multicolored flower), select Albums , and then choose the Screenshots folder.

Use this method if you unlock your iPhone's screen by pressing a round button at the bottom-center part of your iPhone's screen. If you don't have a round button at the bottom of your iPhone's face, use this method instead.

steps.title: Press the Home button and the Lock button at the same time.
steps.content: Press the Home button and the Lock button at the same time. If your iPhone is an iPhone 6 or later, the Lock button is on the right side of the phone. If it's an earlier model, the Lock button is on the top. When you release your fingers from the buttons, the screen will briefly flash white. [2] X Research source

steps.content: Find the image, app, or webpage you want to screenshot. When screenshotting, everything on your screen at the time of the screenshot will be captured in the image.

steps.title: Activate Siri.
steps.content: Activate Siri. You can do this by either pressing and holding the side button on your phone, or by saying "Hey, Siri" out loud.

steps.title: Say "Take a screenshot."
steps.content: Say "Take a screenshot." Siri will immediately take a screenshot of the screen you're on.

steps.title: View your screenshot in the Photos app.
steps.content: View your screenshot in the Photos app. To do so, tap the Photos app (the white icon with a multicolored flower), select Albums , and then choose the Screenshots folder.

steps.title: Open your iPhone's Settings .
steps.content: Open your iPhone's Settings . It's a grey gear icon on your Home Screen. If you don't see it there, you'll find it in the Utilities folder in your app library. [3] X Research source This method teaches you how to use an accessibility feature called AssistiveTouch, which makes it easy to take screenshots on iPhones with broken or difficult-to-reach buttons.

steps.title: Go to Accessibility > Touch > AssistiveTouch.
steps.content: Go to Accessibility > Touch > AssistiveTouch . It's the first option. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the "AssistiveTouch" switch to turn it on .
steps.content: Tap the "AssistiveTouch" switch to turn it on . This adds a small white dot to the right side of the screen. [5] X Research source Tapping this dot opens a menu with several quick-access functions. Once you add the tool that takes screenshots to this menu, it'll be easy to capture a screenshot with one finger. You can tap and drag the dot somewhere else on the screen if you'd like.

steps.title: Tap Customize Top Level Menu.
steps.content: Tap Customize Top Level Menu . It's just below the AssistiveTouch switch.

steps.title: Tap the + next to "6 icons."
steps.content: Tap the + next to "6 icons." It's at the bottom-right corner. This changes "6 icons" to "7 icons."

steps.title: Tap the + at the upper-right corner.
steps.content: Tap the + at the upper-right corner. A list of apps and features will expand.

steps.title: Select Screenshot and tap Done.
steps.content: Select Screenshot and tap Done . This adds a Screenshot option to the menu on the screen. You can tap the back button to exit the menu now.

steps.title: Tap the grey dot on the screen when you are ready to take a screenshot.
steps.content: Tap the grey dot on the screen when you are ready to take a screenshot. This opens the AssistiveTouch menu, where you'll now see a Screenshot option.

steps.title: Tap Screenshot to capture your screenshot.
steps.content: Tap Screenshot to capture your screenshot. You may have to scroll down to find this option. Tapping it will temporarily remove the AssistiveTouch window from your screen, and then take a snapshot of your iPhone screen's contents. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Open your iPhone's Settings .
steps.content: Open your iPhone's Settings . It's a grey gear icon on your Home Screen. If you don't see it there, you'll find it in the Utilities folder in your app library. This method will teach you how to set up a tapping gesture to take a screenshot on your iPhone.

steps.title: Go to Accessibility > Touch > Back Tap.
steps.content: Go to Accessibility > Touch > Back Tap . Back Tap is the last option on the menu.

steps.title: Tap Double Tap or Triple Tap.
steps.content: Tap Double Tap or Triple Tap . You can choose either one of these options. If you choose Double Tap you'll have to tap the back of your iPhone twice to take a screenshot, and if you choose Triple Tap you'll need to tap three times.

steps.title: Choose Screenshot.
steps.content: Choose Screenshot . You might have to scroll to see this option, as the options are sorted alphabetically. Once you've picked an option, you can close the Settings app. The option you choose will save automatically.

steps.title: Tap on the back of your iPhone two or three times to take a screenshot.
steps.content: Tap on the back of your iPhone two or three times to take a screenshot. The amount of taps depends on if you chose Double Tap or Triple Tap . If you have a case on your phone, you may need to tap a bit harder. Cases might also interfere with the tapping gesture, and you might need to tap a few times until your phone can tell you're doing a Back Tap gesture.

steps.content: View your screenshot in the Photos app. To do so, tap the Photos app (the white icon with a multicolored flower), select Albums , and then choose the Screenshots folder.
